name.text: 6.3.3.1 Logs to base 10 and natural logs

questiontext.text:
Logs to base 10 and natural logs

In practice only two kinds of logarithms are commonly used, those to base 10, written \(\log_{10}\) and those to base \(e\), written \(\log_{e}\) or more usually \(\ln\) or \(\log\) (called natural logarithms).

Most scientific calculators will determine the logarithm to base \(10\) and to base \(e\).

For example, \(\log_{10} 13=1.11394\) (implying \(10^{1.11394}=13\)), \(\log 23 =\ln 23=3.13549\) (implying \(e^{3.13549}=23\)).
